title: RBS could buy back its own shares to aid Government sell-off
text:
0.00 
Government is slowly selling off its 73pc stake in Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) 
Royal Bank of Scotland could buy back its own shares to help the Government offload its 73pc stake in the bank, its chief executive said. 
The Government sold a 5.4pc stake in RBS at a loss of £1bn in August and has targeted the sale of three-quarters of its stake in the next five years. 
"I would rather participate as the Government is selling down ... I think it's probably the best thing for all investors, where excess capital goes back through buy-backs," Ross McEwan told the Bank of America Merrill Lynch Banking & Insurance Conference in London. 
Mr McEwan said the bank, rescued by a £46bn government bailout during the 2007/09 financial crisis, was on track to meet key financial targets. 
RBS has said it is aiming for a core Tier 1 capital ratio of 13pc and plans to return any capital above that level, with share buy-backs an option. 
Mr McEwan also said the bank continued to be affected by issues relating to past misconduct. 
"The potential conduct and litigation settlements have to be factored into this progress," he said. "We're dealing with these as quickly and as prudently as possible but they will continue to be a drag on this business for the next six to 12 months." 
Authorities in the US are investigating claims the bank misled investors in mortgage-backed securities in the United States. British regulators are examining its treatment of struggling small firms (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
